content.description: Start on some difficult friction moves to up to a  unique feature. Tricky slab climbing with all the feet going the wrong way with a “spine” to use as holds the the  left. Makes for lots of sideways climbing. After the technical slab, scramble some 5.0 terrain (runout) until reaching the final steep corner. This route packs a large diversity of climbing into 8 bolts. One of my favorites! (Totally unbiased opinion)
content.location: Locate the clean slab, lowest and left most at Janky

content.description: Start in the center of the buttress and climb up past an awkward slab cux until you can get established before the middle, steeper bulge. Crank the bulge (crux) until you gain the ledge below the top. Climb a steep flake to the anchors.

When confronted with the somewhat scary nature of climbing the upper wall, an onlooker remarked: "Well, climbin' ain't beanbag!"Climb the line of bolts to the right of Frozen, starting at a raised ledge right of the hang out spot at the base. While well bolted, the climbing on the upper wall is kinda head's-up, as the slab exists menacingly below you. It should remind you that climbing is, in fact, not beanbag.

Like its neighbor in Rumney, this is a roadside crack that is named different than its grade. Start on Beanbag for a couple of bolts until you can exit right and climb the splitter crack up past ledges to a tree.
content.protection: Bolts, gear, lower off the tree.
content.location: Right side of Janky. You can see this from the boulderfield.

content.description: This wall looked like nothing until it was cleaned. Now if offers a handful of routes on nice gray rock.
